title: Does the bass guitar sound good when played alone? - Quora

response.answer_text: Michael Manring, a great solo bassist and a genius, notes that the bass’ low notes contain a very rich set of harmonic overtones, creating a lustrous, burnished, and complex tone. This he posits this makes the bass an ideal solo instrument. And he’s right, a bass can sound wonderful on it own, with a lot of richness and complexity inherent in the tone of the instrument. And many posters have posted great examples of wonderful solo bass recordings. Ariane is showing you the way! If you know you love bass, then I would say definitely go for it and never look back. On the other hand, the scale length of the bass, and the density of harmonics, requiring more open voicings in your chords (as Ariane mentioned in her excellent post), mean that it is more physically demanding than and technically challenging than, for example, a classical acoustic guitar or piano. You might be able to progress further faster in solo playing on a classical acoustic guitar or piano than on bass, and there is a lot more of a repertoire to learn and play on those instruments. As long as you’re just playing for yourself and close friends and family you may find you get more enjoyment and traction more quickly with something other than electric bass. Now I play bass because I love it. I’ve played in bands for years and I love playing in a band, being part of a rhythm section, and making the music feel great, so that people can’t help but move their feet or bob their heads. I will also take a solo, given the opportunity and the right musical space, and I enjoy taking a good solo immensely. There are a lot of great ways to take a good bass solo, too. It’s great when it goes off well. But taking a solo with a band and playing a solo set are two different animals! I do spend a lot of time playing by myself, and I admire many solo bassists, so I have been working on building up a solo repertoire. My relative lack of chops is definitely holding me back in this effort. But I focus on being musical, and if my solo music is simpler than Jaco’s, Manring’s, or Bedrosian’s, so be it. I have yet to perform anything live though. I have played for a few friends and family, and I can manage to keep a spark going for 15 or 20 minutes. The thing is I enjoy doing it even if I never actually perform this material. So in a way it’s gravy for me. But eventually I will hit an open mic and put my feet to the fire. There is nothing quite like performing!

Oh, I very much think so! If you like the sound of bass, then go for it :) A few of my solo bass heroes are: Michael Manring, Steve Lawson, Jeff Schmidt, Cody Wright, Victor Wooten, Steve Bailey, Zander Zon… and many many more. Bass guitar is still a fairly young instrument. There is lots of room to create and innovate. Find your own sound, create your own thing, it is awesomely fun and rewarding. To make a bass sound great on its own it is helpful to keep in mind that due to its low frequencies more than one note played at the same time can sound muddy. To avoid that spread out the way you “voice” the chord (knowledge of compound intervals and chord inversions comes in handy here. If you don’t know theory yet, think of it this way: if something sounds muddy, see if you can play one of the notes involved an octave higher).Also tinker with sound settings by boosting mids and highs and rolling off the low end.Sometimes bassists will string or tune their solo basses differently in oder to get to higher notes. One way to do that is to string them ADGC instead of EADG. Or detune them to what sounds good (and doesn’t break the string).Playing six string is great for solo bass because: you have the higher string and more options to spread out voicings due to having the extra strings.Technology is your ally. Here are a few of my favorite tools to give you ideas for solo bass adventures:delay pedalsloopersenvelope filtersthe POGmany more (it can be addictive)Her are a few of my pieces. Electric bass work has grown more melodic as the years go by and people create new sounds and styles.Jack Bruce is my idol. Listen to his work on the live "Wheels of Fire" Cream Album.James Jamerson did some beautiful work as a studio man for Motown. "How Sweet It Is" by Junior Walker is a good example (not James Taylor).Listen to the bass lines in "Tuesday Afternoon" by the Moody Blues.Listen to "Brown Eyed Girl" and "Into the Mystic" by Van Morrison.I'm not talking shred or complex bass here. I'm talking about melodic lines that will "sound good" when played alone.I am also partial to "White Rabbit" (Jefferson Airplane version, not Great Society - listen to both to see what a good arrangement can do for a song). Also "Sympathy for the Devil" by the Stones.At some point you'll be singing along to your bass part because it sounds good.

Thanks for the A2A Rami Maroun. A bass is indeed very important to many musical styles, as it lays the foundation of song together with the drums. It is also a fantastic solo instrument! A bass guitar has a large frequency range from very low to quite high, especially when you play a 5- or 6-string bass. This gives a lot of possibilities for writing interesting solo pieces. Just look at the examples in the other answers. Making a bass sound good as a solo instrument can be a challenge. What sounds good in a band usually doesn’t sound as good in a solo piece and vice versa. I can certainly recommend to take some lessons if that is an option for you and also ask the teacher this question. A teacher that understands what you would like to achieve, can help you choose the right type of bass, bass amplifier and effects. Good luck and have lots of fun exploring the bass guitar! — Edit — My favourite bass-solo, as an example of some heavier music:

Absolutely! The bass guitar is a monster of an instrument, and is vital in so many genres of music. One of my favorite things about it is how versatile it can be, and how much ground the instrument can cover on its own. There are a lot of guys out there doing solo bass, although a lot of it is looper based, so that's something to take into consideration. Also I think you need a very firm control over your instrument in order to really achieve an entertaining solo performance, which takes a LOT of hard work and practice. Take this video of Victor Wooten playing Stevie Wonder’s “Isn't She Lovely” as an example. Really listen through the whole thing, it's truly incredible and inspiring. Victor Wooten - Isn't She Lovely But ultimately it's up to you! Any instrument can really fill a solo or a backing role, it's all about how you choose to play it!

Well, in the hands of an average bass player, no, because the bass player is usually required to play quite basic single notes underpinning the chordal structure of a song, so you are always wanting the other instruments to come in and be reinforced by the bass. I came to Bass playing after 11 years of playing the guitar. Because I had the chord structures of countless hits in my head, when I came to playing bass in covers bands at the time, I found it very easy indeed. In fact i can honestly say (do not wish to sound egotistical) I don’t believe I have ever dropped a ‘bum’ note playing bass, throughout many bands. When playing complex jazz standards, though, definitely. At first I find I need the ‘dots’, or the chord-sheet. Any players like Pino Palladino, or Mark King, though would sound awesome playing solo in a front room. I happen to believe that a bass needs to be fairly tight and simple to let the music flow. I do not like ‘fancy’ bassists.

A couple of years ago I took up the bass guitar and played it in the school band. From that I fell in love with bass playing. A student at school two years older than me had been playing for a couple years longer than me and was on his way to studying at the conservatorium of music. I will never forget his use of a loop station. Mostly, he would start with a rhythm which he would loop, then add the all-important bass line and also loop that, then he'd add a few extra chordal notes to fill out the backing before finally playing very skilfully a melody of either improvisation, or a melody he had written, or even a variation of a well-known song. The world needs more people who are as creative as him, he inspired me to have fun with all of my music. While I have already learnt a lot of other instruments, bass is still one of my favourites because he showed me how amazing it can sound, both in a group and solo. I'm grateful.

It largely depends on your skill, but I think that it does actually. But if you plan on playing solo often you will need to get a very firm grasp on your rudimentary skills such as your sense of timing, rhythm, and melody. It would help also for you to learn to use a looping pedal if you really want to up your solo performances. I would highly advise watching solo performances from bassists like Victor Wooten, Jaco Pastorius, Markus Miller, Steve Bailey, etc. This can give you a good idea of some of the capabilities that a solo bass player can do, but it's good to remember that before you can play at that level, you need to practice your basics and become a competent bass player first, because within those foundations you will find yourself grasping at straws musically when you try to solo or perform. This is something I've learned from personal experience. Be patient and keep at it.

Depends who’s playing it. Jaco Pastorius could make a bass guitar sound amazing playing just by himself (Portrait of Tracy, his cover of Purple Haze). But Jaco was a genius, and played with other people too (Weather Report, Joni Mitchell, etc.).However music is about playing with people as well as for people. As talented as Segovia was, I can’t listen to him for hours on end. I can listen to Bach concertos, Mozart, Beethoven and Mahler Symphonies hours on end, as well as Motown, the Beatles, REM, Tom Petty, Johnny Cash etc..Hope that answers your question.

A player who is in command of their sound can, indeed, sound incredible playing solo. However, it’s been my experience that a great solo bass sound and a sound that fits in well with a band are two completely different animals. Many great solo sounds have harmonic elements that are in the range of six-string guitars. When a sound like that gets mixed in with real guitars, frequencies clash and the sound can get muddy and indistinct. Onstage, I get a lot of different tones from my bass, and it’s instinctive to me to switch these sounds at will. Adjusting the pickup mix and EQ on the fly is as integral to my sound as my right hand technique. Part of being an electric bass player is knowing your gear and how to get the most out of it.

Yeah, if you’re Jaco Pastorius. For an actual bass “song,” not a solo—which have been amply listed already—check out “Portrait of Tracy” from his debut album. But really, the bass is a musical instrument, and in the right hands, it’s as musical as any other. Edgar Meyer, an extremely versatile double bassist who plays bluegrass AND classical music, recorded Bach’s Suite for Unaccompanied Cello (a benchmark piece for virtuoso cellists), and it sounds great.

It great learning any instrument. Jim Morrison once sang, “ when the music is your special friend. Dance on fire it attends. Music is your only friend. Until the end. Until the end. Until the end…” Something like that… Happy 50th. Birthday Doors' first album… P.S. you don't have to be in a band to play a bass or any instrument. You can play along with the radio, your computer, tapes, or albums. I'm in between bands and writing a lot of originals, but to keep my chops up I usually play along with the radio. To tell you the truth I don't know how many songs that I know ( been playing 51 years now ). Some people call me “ Jukebox.”

Absolutely. Some of my most enjoyed experiences have been going to concerts put on by one person with a bass guitar. Now, if you want to do this and be successful at it, be prepared to invest a lot of time. These people I refer to had obviously paid their dues, and were very, very good. They also usually sang, and/or did other things. Good luck!

Hells yes, it does. And there are some great artists out there who have shown it to be so. Here’s Gonzalo Silva, who does the singer/songwriter thing but with a bass rather than an acoustic guitar: Despiertate '06 Victor Wooten’s first solo album is bass, vocals, and drums. It depends on who’s playing it. I can’t access YouTube on this computer, but go and look up Jaco Pastorius Berliner Jazztage 1979. It’s a 45 minute long show, and it’s just him alone on the bass. It’s awesome. I’m not playing with anyone at the moment, and I’m not nearly as good as that guy was (no one is, LOL), but I’m happy playing alone or to backing tracks. Playing with other people is fun, though, you should try it. Good luck!

Only time I play Bass alone is when I’m practising ! It’s so much better to get together with others, mainly a drummer and a chord instrument like piano or guitar. This is a basic rhythm section in most bands. Then once you get to know how you all play together you can add others to the band such as singers or sax and brass players. Have fun !

It can and should as much as other instruments. I find that it depends on the characteristics of the bass, strings, amp and effects. In a recording, a good test to see if it sounds good is to solo the track. The best bass parts, in my opinion are the ones that have lots of musical “nutrition” in them, i.e. they support the melody and cushion the rhythm.

Yes, it sounds great alone. Plus, when combined with effects, you can sound like you’re playing in a concert hall. Out of curiosity, what are you thinking of? Noodling around while watching TV? Or dedicated arrangements for a solo bass?

Look up solo bass on YouTube and you will find lots of examples of great playing. Try these: "A Lasting Ember" on solo 7 string Fretless Bass by Eric Czar Amazing bass guitar solo by Aram Bedrosian Victor Wooten Super Solo

This is probably the most important question a beginning electric bass musician or beginning electric guitar musician can ask themselves. Here is why. Every musician has either a “bass ear” or a “guitar ear.” If your ear prefers guitar notes it will never prefer bass notes and if your ear prefers bass notes it will never prefer guitar notes. What you need to do is spend some time at a guitar shop playing guitars and basses to find your preference. I hope that helped.

yes, if you play bass riffs, like Hysteria by Muse, or Californication by RHCP, there are a lot of awesome bass songs, also check this channel TommyLeeDepp , its just sooooooooooooo COOOL!!!!!!!!! you can impress the whole word with these only bass songs!

To a bassist - sure. To a non-bassist… not so much, unless you’re a real great player. Bass is more or less a supporting instrument - and there is NOTHING wrong with that. I, as a player, embrace it. But I’m not keen on folks hearing me all alone.

You can do some cool bass stuff. I have seen many artists do cool stuff with loopers or crazy bass solos, but it doesn’t really appeal to the masses. You can’t really serenade somebody with a bass like you can with a guitar. It just seems like you are trying to force an instrument to do something that would be better suited with something else.
Google Victor Wooten. Nuff said.
